name: Certificate of conformity for all materials submitted at least 10 working days before the commencement of works (steel bars, couplers, grout, sheath, centralisers, grout tubes, nail heads, bearing plates, facing concrete/shotcrete).
Acceptance Criteria – Certificates demonstrate compliance with AS/NZS ISO 9001, AS 4671, AS/NZS 4680, AS 1112.3, AS 1214, AS 4131, ASTM D3350/D1784, TfNSW B80, TfNSW R68, TfNSW 3211, TfNSW 3557.
Submission of grout mix proportions, additives or admixtures (if used), and test certificates at least 10 working days before the commencement of grouting.
Acceptance Criteria – Grout conforms to Table R64.1.

Construction Program and Method Statement submitted at least 10 working days before the commencement of works (installation, grouting, testing, facing). The Method Statement and Construction Program includes the information listed in R64 Cl 3.1 .
Acceptance Criteria – Program and methodology approved by Principal.

Principal is notified at least 2 working days before completion of exacavation of a 'lift'. The exposed slope face is inspected by a qualified Geotechnical Engineer engaged by the designer of the soil nail structure.
Acceptance Criteria – Written inspection record and acceptance of face condition.
Submission of Suitability Test records for test nails prior to permanent nail installation.
Acceptance Criteria – Test nails achieve criteria in Table R64.3 (creep <2mm @6–60min, <1mm @60–180min).

Air Monitoring - During the drilling of soil nails, the drilling rig should be equipped with a dust extraction unit to minimise dust emissions and ensure a safe working environment. If the drilling rig does not have a dust extraction unit installed, continuous monitoring of air quality must be conducted throughout the operation. Should air quality levels exceed acceptable thresholds, immediate measures must be implemented to control and mitigate the dust generated by the drilling activities
Soil nail drilling setout, alignment, and hole logs recorded. Soil nails have adequate clearance from nearby structures and are within the tolerances listed in R64 Cl 3.4.2.
Acceptance Criteria – R64 Cl 3.4.2 (≤5° deviation, –0/+100mm depth, ).
Bleed testing - One sample of grout from each batch of grout provided to determine the amount of bleeding in accordance with ASTM C940 and the requirements specified in Clause 2.2.7.
Acceptance Criteria – Compliance with ASTM C940 & R64 Cl 2.2.7
Fluidity testing - One sample of grout from each batch of grout provided to determine the fluidity in accordance with ASTM C939 and the requirements specified in Clause 2.2.7.
Acceptance Criteria – Compliance with ASTM C939 & R64 Cl 2.2.7
Compressive strength test - The compressive strength (32MPa@7days, 40MPa@28 days), sampled and tested at the following frequencies:
Acceptance Criteria - Compliance with Test Method TfNSW T375 at the frequencies shown in Table R64.2
Soil nail installation and grouting conformity records submitted including the those listed in R64 Cl 3.4.3.10.

The bearing plate and galvanized nuts are fitted at the head of the soil nail concentrically to the steel reinforcement. There is void-free contact over the full area of the bearing plate and the nuts are locked tight to the soil nails (after the grout has attained a minimum 32MPa compressive strength).
Acceptance Criteria – Voids eliminated, plates concentric ±5mm, perpendicular ±3°. Lock nuts after grout 32 MPa.
Submission of Acceptance Test results for permanent nails within one week of completion.
Acceptance Criteria – Test nails achieve criteria in Table R64.4.
Final conformity records for installed nails submitted (including changes, extra nails, spacing/length variations).
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
R64-02 - Strip Drains & Horizontal PVC Drains
Strip drains minimum 150mm wide HDPE single or double cuspated type plastic core encased in non-woven geotextile to TfNSW R63 strength class A and application class G3.

Provide a certificate of compliance verifying that the flexible strip filter complies with all the requirements of this specification together with test results reported on NATA endorsed test documents. The certificate is for tests not more than six (6) months old.
Mark each Lot of strip filter supplied clearly with the following information on an adhesive label:
(b) The nominal height and width of the strip filter;
Where specified on the Drawings, place flexible strip filter drains behind the concrete facing, at spacings of 3m.

Installation and testing of soil nails together with installation of horizontal drains and flexible strip filter drains must commence immediately after excavation is completed. The time the exposed excavated face is left unsupported must be kept to a minimum to prevent any deterioration of the excavated face.

During placement of concrete, protect the drainage system against contamination to ensure proper functioning. Shotcrete must not cover or impair the function of slotted pipe drain or strip drain outlets which protrude through the shotcrete layer. You may use temporary plugs to protect such outlets during the shotcreting process.

Submit records for the installation of strip drains, within three working days of completion of installation. Within the said three working days from completion of installation and after submission of conformity records, present the slope area to be covered by shotcrete to the Principal for inspection.
Acceptance Criteria – Submission of Records to Principal

Set out the drain holes as detailed. The maximum allowable tolerances for locating the position of drain holes are ± 100 mm vertically, ± 300 mm horizontally. Provide facilities to enable the inspection of the drain hole locations by the Principal. Notice of intention to commence drilling, at least 3 working day(s) prior to the event.
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will inspect the set out of the drain hole locations, prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point

Drill the holes for the horizontal drains to an inclination of between 3° and 8° dipping towards the exposed slope face or to the inclinations shown on the Drawings. Drillholes must be at least 150 mm in diameter to allow installation of the slotted outer UPVC pipe. Holes must be smooth, clean and true to size.

Drill holes in a straight alignment. Maximum permissible deviation of the holes must not exceed 2° (as measured on a horizontal plane). Deviation from straight must not exceed 25 mm in any 2 m length of hole.

Installation of Drain Pipes - submission of Detailed drilling records for each hole including drilling method and equipment, types of materials penetrated and presence of groundwater with related depths, drilling rates, difficulties and breakdowns.
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will consider the submitted documents prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point.

Install an outer and an inner UPVC drain pipe in each drillhole, with the unslotted 120° of the circumference section of the pipe at the bottom. The pipe must be jointed either as spigot and socket joints, or as butt joints with a sleeve extending about 50 mm over the end of each pipe.
Wrap the geotextile filter fabric around the inner pipe with an overlap length of 25 mm and fix with PVC tape at 300 mm centres.
After installation of an outer pipe, tightly plug the annular space between the drilled hole and the outer pipe with cement mortar for a length of at least 0.5 m at the outlet end of the hole.
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
R68-01 - Shotcrete Work Without Steel Fibres
Submission of nominated shotcrete mix to be used in the works submitted to Principal atleast 5 working days prior to use of mix.
Acceptance Criteria - All details from R68 Clause 3.2 to Clause 3.7 inclusive and certification

Variation of Nominated Mix - Details of variations to nominated mix submitted to Principal prior to commencement of production. Variations to the mix shall adhere to provisions outlined in R68 Cl 3.9.
Acceptance Criteria - Variations to mix approved by Principal

Trial of shotcrete mix - Prior to commencement of construction, test panels shall be constructed for each base mix and for each nominated nozzle operator. Carry out sampling and testing for compressive strength, density, and permeability. Where it is shown that same materials, mix designs, equipment, procedures and personnel have given satisfactory results in similar works, the Principal may exercise his discretion and accept the first shotcrete placed in the Works as the Test Panel.
Acceptance Criteria - Trial Mix and Acceptance by Principal (or as required)

Surface Preperation - Notifcation of each intention to commence surface preparation with details of the method to be used at least two working days prior to commencing. Request to Principal for direction on the need for pressure grouting.
Surface Preperation - The earths surface has been compacted and trimmed to line and grade. All loose soil or other material has been removed from the trimmed surface.
Prior to commencement of shotcrete, excessive absorbition of mixing water prevented by:
(a) Prewetting all earth surfaces to be shotcreted but keep the surface free of free water; or

(b) Installing a moisture barrier system to stop the movement of moisture from the newly placed shotcrete into the earth. If a sheet materials is used, wrinkling or folding has been provented to stop voids being formed behind the moisture barrier.
Reinforcing Steel - The reinforcement material supplier is certified by the Australian Certification Authority for Reinforcing Steels (ACRS) for the supply of reinforcement material.
Reinforcement is supported and is clear of the surface to be shotcreted maintaing a minimum cover of 50 mm (as per the project drawings).
Slump Test - The slump of the concrete tested immediately prior to discharge in accordance with AS 1379. The frequency of sampling has been conducted in accordance with Annexure R68/L.
Reference - R68 Cl 6.4, AS 1379, Annexure R68/L
Addition of water to mixed batch of concrete shall be subject to the following:
(a) Less than 45 minutes have elapsed since cement was added to the aggregate;

(b) Immediately after the addition of any water, operate the mixing mechanism at mixing speed for a time equivalent to at least 30 revolutions of the mechanism, and for such additional time as may be necessary to re-establish uniformity of the mix;
(c) The total quantity of water added is not more than 9 kg/m3 and is such that the nominated water/cement ratio is not exceeded;
(d) The quantity of water added is measured and recorded;
(e) The slump is checked after the water has been added.
Temperature - Concrete shall not be used if the temperature at any time up to the time of discharge from transport vehicles is less than 10°C or more than 32°C.
Acceptance Criteria - Check & Verify Temperature at Discharge (>10°C, <32°C)

Shotcrete Equipment - Performance records of proposed shotcrete equipment submitted to Principal. Equipment is cabale of allowing the shotcrete to leave the nozzle in a continuous uninterrupted stream. Equipment must be capable of maximising compaction and quality whilst minimising rebound and overspray.
Acceptance Criteria - Verification of Equipment Performance Records
Shotcrete thickness - Thickness of shotcrete application routinely checked using probes during the application.
○ At least 2 working days prior, give notice of each intention to shotcrete.
○ At least 4 working hours prior to the proposed commencement of application (unless otherwise allowed by the Principal)
○ Submission of Certificate of Conformity in respect of surface preparation, reinforcement and embedments.
Acceptance Criteria - Submitted documents approved by Principal. Surveillance/Audit conducted by Principal.
Surface Finish - Shotcrete surfaces are the undisturbed natural finish as applied from nozzle.

Tolerances - The maximum variation in alignment, grade, and dimensions of the structures from the established alignment, grade and dimensions (excluding thickness) shown on the Drawings must be ± 50 mm, unless specified otherwise on the Drawings. The tolerance in thickness must be as shown on the Drawings.
Temperature and Rain - Shotcrete shall not be placed under the following conditions:
(a) During rain or when rain is imminent
(b) When the air temperature in the shade is below below 5°C or above 38°C
Wet Curing - Wet curing is apploied to surfaces immediately after the completion of the application and finishing operations. Water used for curing conforms to AS 1379.

Curing Compound - Certificate of Conformity from the supplier for curing compound provided to the Principal prior to use, supported by test certificates from a laboratory with appropriate NATA registration. Application of curing compound conforms to R68 Cl 8.3 requirements.
Acceptance Criteria - Principal acceptance of curing compound
Shotcrete sampled and tested for conformity with R68 and the Project Drawings during the progress of the work in accordance with Annexure R68/L for:
Acceptance Criteria - Test results compliant with R68 and Project Project
Visual inspection of all completed shotcrete work must ensure conformity with compaction and finish requirements
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Rock source and quality certificates submitted to Principal prior to delivery.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Submission of supplier conformity
Rock armour comprises of hard durable rock of medium to high strength (point load strength 1 or greater).
Individual rock minimum dimension of 0.5m (target weight 0.5tn to 2tn). Placement of 2.5tn of rock per metre length of rock armour.
Rock armour placed by long reach excavator following site preparation and de-vegetation.
Placement of rock armour to specified locations as per Project Drawings with direction by TfNSW geotechnical representative.
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification

An environmental risk assessment workshop carried out to identify all the environmental constraints associated with the Work Under the Contract and address the environmental risks associated with the constraints and activities you propose to undertake. The Principal provided notification of at least ten (10) days prior to the workshop with an agenda and any supporting information to allow for representatives of the Principal to also attend the workshop.
Acceptance Criteria - Notify and Carry out Environmental Risk Assessment Workshop
CEMP (and associated Sub-Plans and/or EWMS) as well as the CEMS documents listed in Clause 3.1 submitted at least 10 working days prior to the proposed commencement of works.
Acceptance Criteria - Acceptance of CEMP by Principal

At least five ten (10) working days prior, provide to the Principal a copy of the EWMS for working in or near the environmentally sensitive areas and written notice that the environmentally sensitive areas are clearly delineated with locations and boundaries signposted. The identified sensitive area is adjacent to the Wollemi National Park, which is part of the Greater Blue Mountains World Heritage Area.
Acceptance Criteria -Submission and acceptance of EWMS
Submission of evidence of receipt of the approval, licence and/or permit from relevant authorities at least five working days prior to the activity,.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission and acceptance of approvals
Contaminated Land - Where contaminated land is identified, a Remediation Action Plan with relavant procedures is to be submitted (at least 5 working days prior to action).
Acceptance Criteria - Principal acceptance of submitted documents
Transportation of Waste - Submission of a completed and signed copy of Offsite Waste Disposal “approved notice” and supporting documents, as listed under items (a) to (g) in Clause 4.11.3
Acceptance Criteria - Submission and Acceptance of Offsite Waste Disposal Documentation

Pre-construction Land Condition Assessment - Pre-construction land condition assessment report submitted for each area the Contractor’s site facilities shall occupy (including evidence of any necessary statutory and environmental approvals)
Acceptance Criteria - Submission and acceptance of Pre-constructiong Land Condition Assessment
Burning Off - Burning of any material on the Construction Site, including disposal of cleared and grubbed vegetation by burning off, is not permitted.
Notification to the EPA Regional Manager of at least two people, including their telephone numbers, who will be contactable by the EPA on a 24 hour basis
Acceptance Criteria - Submission of worker details to EPA.
Air Quality - Air Quality Management Sub-Plan implemented. Construction activities planned and carried out to avoid where practicable, or minimise, the generation of dust and vehicle emissions.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Check & Verify

Flora and Fauna Management Sub-Plan prepared and included as part of the CEMP. Effective environmental controls to protect all native flora, fauna, and fish from the impact of construction activites implemented.

Environmental Noncoformities - If environmental obligations under the contract have not been met during works (or have the potential to cause harm to the environment), a hold point shall apply until rectification, and details of measures implemented to prevent recurrence.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission and acceptance of rectification details.
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Implementation of soil and water management measures in accordance with approved ESCP.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - ESCP approval and daily monitoring

ESC Register - Maintain a register of inspection and maintenance of erosion control and sediment capture measures, dates or discharge, water treatment (flocculation) performed, discharge water quality, volumes of sediment removed from each device, and daily rainfall.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission of ESC Register

Construction Site Dewatering - Implementation of dewatering procedure for all identified construction activities. Inspection of the entire system, including intakes and outlets, pumping and discharge locations, prior to commencement of dewatering. Records of dewatering to be kept as per G38 Cl. 3.4.5.
Acceptance Criteria - Constrution Site Dewatering Records

Stockpile Management - Erosion control and sediment capture measures installed prior to stockpiling material. ESC measures maintained regularly to divert offsite stormwater, manage onsite stormwater runoff and stabilise stockpiles.
Acceptance Criteria - Comply with G38 Cl 3.5 provisions.
Reference - G38 Cl. 3.5, TfNSW Technical Guideline EMS-TG-010: Stockpile Site Management and the BLUE BOOK guidelines.
Environmental Work Method Statement - For work in and adjacent to waterways, an Environmental Work Method Statement (EWMS) has been prepared in accordance with TfNSW G36 and G38 Cl. 3.7.1.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission and Implementation of EWMS

If works commencing require installation of erosion control and sediment capture measures not previously captured in the ESCP, submission of Drawings cinluding the sections to be disturbed must be submitted. The submission of these sections must occur at least 10 working days prior to disturbance of the surface.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission and acceptance of updated ESCP to Principal.

Disturbance of the existing surface on a section of the Site, other than for the installation of erosion and sediment capture measures. Written advice that the measures described in the ESCP and included on the drawing submitted progressively for that section of the Site have been implemented or the date by which implementation will be completed. The advice must be forwarded at least five working days before the works are to commence.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission and acceptance of updated ESCP to Principal.
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Submission of Traffic Management Plan (TMP) including staging, TGS, VMP, PMP and risk assessment.
Acceptance Criteria – Submitted 20 working days before ROL application (unless agreed otherwise)

Submission of Road Occupancy Licence (ROL) application and Speed Zone Authorisation (SZA). A copy of the ROL, SZA and relevant Traffic Guidance Scheme Control Plan kept on site at all times when the licence is in operation.
Acceptance Criteria – TGS Submission and Acceptance
Traffic control personnel submitted with current qualifications prior to any work commencing.
Acceptance Criteria – Submission of names, registration numbers and expiry dates

If not previously submitted as part of the TMP, any activity which will affect traffic conditions for a particular section of the Site requires submission of a Traffic Guidance Scheme atleast 3 days prior to its proposed use.
Acceptance Criteria – TGS Submission and Acceptance
Traffic Incident Management Plan submitted to Principal and implemented.
Acceptance Criteria – Submission of TIMP details
Traffic Management Risk Assessment Workshop completed and recorded
Acceptance Criteria - Risk issues recorded and closed out.

Implementation of traffic switch or opening of temporary roadway and detour to traffic. At least one day prior to the intended date of opening the temporary roadways to traffic, notify the Principal in writing that the traffic control measures is conforming and ready for inspection by the Principal.
Acceptance Criteria – A joint inspection with the Principal.
Daily inspection of traffic control measures in place (signs, devices, barriers, pavement markings).
Acceptance Criteria - Daily inspection reports maintained, implemented in accordance with TGS
Monthly reporting to Principal on TMP compliance, delays and incidents
Records of temporary speed zoning (sign placement/removal times)
Acceptance Criteria - Logs maintained and available
Traffic incidents investigated and reported to Principal.
Acceptance Criteria – Incident report submitted to Principal with details and corrective actions
Routine maintenance of existing, temporary or new roadways where applicable
Acceptance Criteria – Roadways kept safe and trafficable
Notify Principal 10 working days prior to opening of completed works to traffic (or section of) – removal of temporary devices
Acceptance Criteria – Permanent line marking, barriers, signs installed
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification

Atleast 7 days pror to any clearing, the Clearing and Grubbing Plan and a report on the presence of weeds and unsound trees shall be submitted. Additionaly, the submission of a written notice that limits of clearing and areas of weed infestation identified in the ecologist report are marked.
Acceptance Criteria - Documents reviewed and approved by Principal.
All construction operations conducted to ensure that there is no damage to any trees outside the limits of clearing specified
Weeds removed and disposed of in accordance with the requirements of the local Council

Measures taken during the operations of clearing and road construction to avoid damaging or destroying threatened flora species and trees which have been marked or otherwise identified for preservation. These measures must include but not be limited to:
(i) fencing around trees clear of the canopy line;
(ii) ensuring no materials are stockpiled and no vehicles are parked under the canopy;
(iii) avoiding excavation or the placing of fill near any tree without advice from an ecologist; and
(iv) routing haul roads and access tracks clear of the canopy
Damage of any kind, including damage to fencing or trees or other vegetation outside the limits of clearing, which occurs during clearing operations, shall be rectified
Acceptance Criteria - Rectification of damage outside of clearing limits (unless otherwise approved)

All trees and stumps, on or within the limits of clearing, and which are unable to be felled and removed by the clearing methods, must be removed by grubbing. Grubbing operations must be carried out both to a depth of 0.5m below the natural surface and 1.5m below the top of the Selected Material Zone.
Holes that remain after trees and stumps have been grubbed have been backfilled promptly with sound material to prevent the infiltration and ponding of water
Acceptance Criteria - Backfill material compacted to at least the relative compaction of the material existing in the adjacent ground
Any clearing beyond the completed formation, as indicated in the Parsons Creek Slope 48865 - Geotechnical Design Drawings (DS2023/000636), requires approval from the Principal
Acceptance Criteria - Submission & approval of extra area to be cleared by Principal
Application to stockpile mulch outside of nominated Site area submitted to the Principal at least ten working days before stockpiling is due to commence.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission & approval of alternative stockpile area
Mulch stockpile located away from drainage lines and watercourses and arranged to minimise damage to natural vegetation and trees.
Stockpiles must be monitored and turned over as required to avoid spontaneous combustion. Restoration of stockpile sites following completion of the work to be carried out.
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
R116 - Heavy Duty Dense Graded Asphalt (Intermediate & Wearing Courses)
Submission of nominated asphalt mix designs (Including items specified in R116 Cl. 2.3.3) at least 7 working days prior to proposed placement.
Acceptance Criteria - Conformance with R116 mix design requirements

Trial Section - Prior to commencement of paving works, the construction of a separate trial section using the plant and personnel proposed for the work for each nominated mix shall occur. Verification checklist and all relevant test results from the trial section demonstrating conformity to the specified requirements shall be submitted to the Principal at least 3 working days prior commencement of paving (at locations other than the trial section)
Acceptance Criteria - Principal review of proposal
Submission of asphalt temperature as per the following:
(a) minimum temperature at which asphalt will be delivered to the paver;
(b) minimum temperature at which initial compaction of the asphalt can still commence;
Acceptance Criteria - Asphalt temperatures included in Project Quality Plan
Traffic and Safety Controls - Traffic and safety controls are in place (eg. PPE, daily plant check)
Acceptance Criteria - Check traffic and safety controls have been implemented as per plan prior to asphalt placement.
Surface prepared to be paved in accordance with AS 2150, including removal of raised extruded thermoplastic road markings and raised pavement markers

Provide to the Principal a signed daily record of the average tackcoat application rate applied to each Lot. Report the tackcoat application rate in terms of residual bitumen and state the percentage dilution of the tackcoat used during spraying.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission of tack coat daily record
Measure and record the temperature of the surface to be paved, and wind velocity at the point of asphalt placing.
Acceptance Criteria - Register of surface temperature and wind velocity
(a) offset by 150 mm from the joint in the underlying layers;
(b) located within 150 mm of the line of change in crossfall;
(c) coincident with final traffic markings, unless otherwise approved by the Principal
(i) located at a minimum of 25 m apart;
(ii) offset by a minimum of 1 m from the joint in the underlying layer;
(iii) formed at the commencement of each paving run;
(iv) formed when a delay in paving causes asphalt temperature to fall below the initial compaction temperature nominated in Clause 3.5.

Temporary Ramps - Temporary ramps constructed at joints for safe trafficking of the work either by placement of asphalt, or by cold milling the existing or new asphalt layer to form the ramp, as appropriate for the application. The length and grade of temporary ramps must be equivalent to those specified for treatment at edges and structures described in Specification TfNSW R101
Compliance Testing shall be carried out for each lot. The Testing Frequencies shall not be less than those listed in Annexure R116/L (Minimum Frequency of Testing)
Submission of the following test reports to the Principal:
(a) combined particle size distribution, binder content and air voids in laboratory compacted mix – within one working day of placing the asphalt;
(b) insitu air voids, course thickness and course shape – within three working days of placing the asphalt.

Straightedge Tolerances - The surface shape of the course within and across traffic lanes must not deviate from the bottom of the straightedge (refer Clause 4.5) laid in any direction by more than the tolerances shown in Table R116.12.
For corrective courses and tie-ins to an existing pavement where nonconforming layer thickness will occur, the following shall be submitted to the Principal:
(a) nominated layer thicknesses which does not conform to specified thicknesses;
(b) work methods capable of producing a dense homogeneous layer at these thicknesses;
(c) areas affected, and evidence that these areas are the absolute minimum necessary
Acceptance Criteria - Principal review of proposal

Nonconforming Lot - Where a HOLD POINT is required to be observed, investigate the causes of the nonconformity, and propose corrective action to prevent recurrence of future nonconformity. Submission of test results for insitu air voids and all properties specified in R116 Cl. 2.2.
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will consider the submitted documents prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point, and will advise whether the nonconforming Lot can be accepted.

Nonconforming Lot - Nonconforming Lots which are not accepted shall be either rectified or replaced. A nonconformity report and details of proposal to rectify or replace the Lot submitted to Principal.
Acceptance Criteria - Principal review of proposal
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
R145 & R142 - Line Marking (Waterborne Paint) & Retroreflective Raised Pavemenet Markers

All works carried out by a pavement marking organisation accredited to the “Painting Contractors Certification Program” (PCCP), administered by CSIRO under the appropriate classes from Category B “Pavement markings".
Pavement marking material meets the required performance criteria (but subject to the limitations for profile pavement markings as stated in R145 Clause 2.1.2)

The proposed pavement marking materials must be appropriate for the pavement and traffic conditions under which they are applied and used, and must satisfy the performance criteria detailed in R145 Clause 5. Provide to the Principal a list of materials, and their limitations under the conditions for which they will be used under the Contract, such as seasonal constraints and potential or known incompatibility with other materials. A current Certificate of Product Conformity issued by APAS for the product proposed to be used must be submitted to the Principal.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission of Material Certificates to Principal
The surface area to be marked is dry and free of dirt, gravel and other loose or foreign material. The area around the marking must is also free of dirt, gravel and other loose or foreign material.
Prior to application of new pavement markings, Principal shall be notified once setout is complete.
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal may inspect the set out prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point
As a guide to achieving optimum long term performance of pavement markings using waterborne paints with large glass beads (Type D-HR), apply the waterborne paint under the following conditions:
(d) adequate protection of markings from traffic during the drying process.
○ Waterborne paint must not be applied when relative humidity is above 85% or when air or road temperatures are below 10°C
Markings applied soon after the bituminous surfacing is placed as an initial sacrificial coat, and then a second coat applied within two to three months later, in a two stage process.

Retroreflective Raised Pavement Markers - Submission of a statement, signed by the supplier, stating that materials meet the respective requirements of R142 Clause 2 at least seven (7) days prior to their proposed use. The statement must include test results from a laboratory registered by NATA for the specified tests or by a laboratory approved by the Principal. Such certificates must be valid for tests conducted no more than 36 months previously
Acceptance Criteria - Submission of Material Statement and Test Results to Principal (7 days prior to use)

Retroreflective raised pavement markers set out to ensure they are placed in accordance with the nominated drawings, TfNSW referenced documents, and to the tolerances required by this Specification. Notification given to Principal once set out is complete.
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal may inspect the set out prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point

Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification

Commence removal of topsoil after completion of clearing and grubbing, and removal of the cleared materials on that section of the Works. Where directed by the Principal, after removal of the topsoil:
(a) stockpile the topsoil within the Site separately from other materials and clear of the Works for use in revegetation, or
(b) stockpile the topsoil as a windrow longitudinally and adjacent to the toe of embankment batter, or
(c) dispose of the topsoil as spoil outside the Site in accordance with Clause 2.7.1; or
(d) if the topsoil has been identified as contaminated material, dispose of the topsoil as spoil in accordance with Clause 2.7.2

Survey Report of existing surface levels, and notification that the set out specified in Clause 1.6.2, including set out of the extent of the Cut/Fill Transition Zone as specified in Clause 3.5.2, have been carried out, at least three working days prior.

Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will consider the submitted documents, inspect the surfaces and set out, and may direct further action prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point. Further action may include altering the limits of the Cut/Fill Transition Zone.

Unsuitable Material - If unsuitable material is found on site, excavate such unsuitable material to the extent directed by the Principal. Provide notification that the unsuitable material has been removed as directed.

Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will consider the submitted documents, inspect the surfaces and set out, and may direct further action prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point. Further action may include altering the limits of the Cut/Fill Transition Zone.
Unsuitable Material - Replace any material that has been removed as unsuitable material with either:
(a) suitable material conforming to Clause 5.2.1; or
(b) if directed, with foundation treatments in accordance with Clause 3

Prior to carrying out any foundation treatments within cuttings (except for Treatment Type C5), tests carried out to determine the CBR and PI values of the material in the floor of the cutting, using the Test Methods specified in Annexure R44/A2.2, and present the floor for inspection by the Principal.
(a) Notification of completion of excavation to:
(i) Designed Floor Level, or Foundation Level, as appropriate; and
(ii) depth specified for Cut/Fill Transition Zone (refer to Clause 3.5.2).
(The submission must be concurrent with the submission for any adjoining Shallow Embankment foundation required by the Hold Point in R44 Clause 3.3.)
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will consider the submitted documents, inspect the floor of the cutting and may direct further action prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point.
After preparation of the embankment foundation area and prior to commencing the foundation treatment, present the area for inspection by the Principal. Submission to Principal:
(b) Notification of completion of clearing operations.
(c) In areas other than beneath Shallow Embankments notification that:
(i) topsoil has been removed in accordance with R44 Clause 2.5; or
(ii) grasses have been flattened/mowed if so shown on the Drawings or specified.
(i) notification that topsoil has been removed and surface excavated in accordance with R44 Clause 3.5.1; and
(ii) CBR and PI test results, if required in accordance with R44 Clause 3.5.1.

Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will consider the submitted documents, inspect the prepared embankment foundation area, and may direct further action prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point.

Submit to Principal proposed source locations, quantities and types of material, and verification of conformity. If imported, verification that all possible sources of the material within the Site have been exhausted or allocated for placing.
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will consider the submitted details and may inspect the source and stockpiles of material prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point.

Proof Roll - Carry out proof rolling on all Lots within the Selected Material Zone and within 1.5 m below the underside of the Selected Material Zone. Where directed by the Principal, carry out proof rolling on all embankment Lots which are deeper than 1.5 m from the underside of the Selected Material Zone.

Acceptance Criteria - Notification of the location, date and time of the proof rolling, and providing verification that the subject layer or surface conforms in all respects except for proof rolling, at least one working day prior

Embankment Batters - Batter surfaces must not have undulations in the general plane of the batter outside of the tolerance specified in R44 Clause 7.9.3, and must be free of rills running down the face of the batter.
Project Manager Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
Client Verify that the Above has been Constructed according to Specification
R132 - Safety Barrier Systems (Removal and Installation)

On a road open to traffic, a suitable traffic management plan shall be implemented, conforming to Specification TfNSW G10, to shield any partly dismantled or partly constructed safety barrier system or any safety barrier system without fully operational end treatments.

Submit, at least 3 working days before the proposed exposure of the safety barrier system without fully operational end treatments, full details of your proposals together with a risk assessment of your proposals.
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will examine the proposals and the associated risk assessment prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point

At least seven (7) days prior to the proposed use of any materials and components supplied, submit to the Principal a signed statement certifying that the materials and components supplied comply with the requirements of R132. Include relevant test reports and a copy of a verification checklist.
Acceptance Criteria - Submission of material test reports and verification checklist to Principle.

Remove all redundant posts, anchors and other in-ground components by extraction or excavation. Following removal of the posts, clean out and backfill the holes. Backfilling and compaction of holes must proceed in 150 mm layers using similar materials to existing surrounding layers. Compact backfill to not less than the density of the surrounding layers.
All other surplus materials resulting from removal of safety barrier systems shall be removed from the site.
Acceptance Criteria -Removal of surplus material from site.

Install pegs in the ground (or mark with paint on hard ground) to mark the start and finish points and line of safety barriers, transitions and end treatments including the line of flare if applicable, before commencing construction. Measure offsets for flares from a line parallel to the adjacent lane line.

Prior to installation of the safety barrier system, a notification that the set out is in accordance with R132, the Project Drawings and the manufacturer’s recommendations, at least 2 working days before the proposed commencement of installation of posts or assembly of components/devices (whichever is earlier).
Acceptance Criteria - The Principal will inspect the set out of the safety barriers prior to authorising the release of the Hold Point.
All permanent safety barrier systems and device installations, maintenance and repairs must be undertaken by ASHTAS Operative accredited individuals.
Acceptance Criteria - Check & Verify Safety Barrier Systems Subcontractor
Installation of the posts must comply with the following requirements:
(a) The posts must be installed to the depth, line and spacing shown on the Drawings, and to the tolerances in R132 Clause 4.5;
(b) The installation process must not cause any structural damage to the post, including any soil plates attached to the post;
(c) The installation must not cause any damage to the pavement beyond 100 mm from any part of any post, including any soil plate attached to the post;

(d) When a lateral force of 1 kN is applied in any direction within the top 200 mm of an installed post but before the rail is secured, the movement of the post at ground level must be not more than 3 mm;

(e) Backfill material around the steel tubes and soil plates of gating leading end treatments, and at Posts Nos 1 and 2 in a Modified Eccentric Loader Terminal (MELT), must be compacted to a minimum 95% relative compaction, measured in accordance with TS 02795.28 (Test Method TfNSW T166);

(f) The disturbed pavement or ground around a post must be trimmed and compacted to a dense, tight, smooth and sealed condition so that resistance to water penetration is similar to that of the adjacent surface.

Unless stated otherwise in the manufacturer’s recommendations and any applicable TfNSW requirements for a particular proprietary safety barrier system or device, tolerances for construction of all safety barrier systems and devices must be as follows:
(b) For line of safety barrier system: ± 20 mm in plan view; and
(c) For departures from the upright axis (vertical or normal to the surface as applicable - see Clause 4.1): ± 15 mm at the top of the barrier.
The height must be measured vertically for systems constructed with vertical posts and normal to the road surface for other systems. Measure the height as follows:
(i) where the barrier is within the pavement, from the pavement surface;
(ii) where the barrier is adjacent to the pavement, from the line of pavement crossfall extended to the barrier line; and
(iii) for all other circumstances, as shown on the Drawings or as directed by the Principal.
